Good animation but story writing needs improvement: The animation was fun to watch specially that you don't see that much Filipino animation online.

The thing that I don't like about this movie is that it has too many dirty jokes that aren't that funny, and I think it would've been done better if the jokes were timed right. The story flow was messy, some parts were fast, some parts were slow. I actually found myself watching this movie with a straight face, i guess i was expecting too much since the teasers hyped me up?

Guess the way the story was written isn't my cup of tea. Kudos to those people who worked on this animation! hope to see more animation projects in the future

Good Overall: I set my expectations low, when I saw the mainstream local actors were the voice of the characters. Its premise as typical cheap romantic comedy gives me a bad vibes because of reputation of poorly-made-overused plot lines that plagues Filipino mainstream cinema. But I still give it a chance because Filipino animations are not common. I like the cultural references and the catch of the story. I think making it as adult, dark comedy animation film is a great move. In short "Hayop Ka!" Exceeds my expectations, 7/10.

IT'S CLICHED, FUN AND QUITE TOUCHING: During the first half of "Hayop Ka," tons of cliches from filipino teleseryes and movies were shown, including some funny jokes and references. But after an argument scene that features Robin Padilla's terrific voice acting, the film actually got better. Despite being quite annoying during the first half, the character of Nymfa won me over due to her journey and the ending wherein I realized that a lot of Filipinas end up with the same situation.

Funny and enjoyable...: When I stumbled upon the 2020 Tagalog animated movie "Hayop Ka!", I had no idea what I was getting myself into here. But I read the synopsis for it, and have to say that I was somewhat intrigued, as "Hayop Ka!" sounded like something definitely aimed at a more mature audience.

And I will say that writers Manny Angeles, Avid Liongoren and Paulle Olivenza definitely managed to put together a story and plot that was every bit as entertaining as it was enjoyable. So yeah, "Hayop Ka!" was a wholesome animated feature for a mature audience. And when I say mature audience I don't mean that it is XXX-rated, but merely that there were references and hits towards lewd nature.

The art style in "Hayop Ka!" was strange, but enjoyably so. Initially I was a bit taken aback by the art style, but it quickly grew on me and I came to enjoy the art style that they used here because it was definitely complimenting the story and the message of the movie.

With "Hayop Ka!" being an animated movie, a proper voice cast ensemble is a must. And luckily they did have that here. While I am not familiar with Tagalog cinema, then I wasn't familiar with a single voice here. But I will say that the voice acting was good and definitely gave the characters life on the screen.

I found "Hayop Ka!" to be an enjoyable surprise of a movie, and definitely is an animated movie that I would recommend for a mature audience that enjoys light-hearted and funny stories. The fact that "Hayop Ka!" was told as an animation wasn't really a hindrance in any way.

My rating of director Avid Liongoren's "Hayop Ka!" lands on a six out of ten stars.

You Filthy Animal, Nimfa XD: Hayop Ka - About the female cat known as Nimfa, who has to decide if she wants to be with her macho boyfriend who she's been with for years or a rich gentlemen guy. The movie has it's ups and downs

Pros:

Character Designs and Animations - Let's go ahead and point this out. I thought the designs for the characters were unique. To the point where I can easily identify where these characters came from. Not only that, but the animation was beautiful!! I enjoyed the movement of these characters!

Repeating Premise with a Surprise - It has been done to death Yes. A female that's tired of her broke life so she wants a chance at the richness and luxury. That's pretty much what Nimfa does in this movie. She leaves her ex to join the rich and luxurious life. Except instead of realizing she was better off with her old life, she doesnt get neither men. Her Ex was now taken and she caught her Rich boyfriend cheating. So the premise is repetitive but there was a nice twist for me!

Roger - If I had to say which character stood out to me more, it was definitely Roger. He was the best character to me in the movie. Because he was trying his best to provide for his girl while staying loyal to her. While admittingly, he is at fault for giving her the same repetitive lifestyle she grown tired of, I felt like he didnt deserve to be lied and cheated on. Plus, his design is pretty hot owo Strong Muscular Dog

Radio Host - I forgot his name but the radio show host straight up tells Nimfa all the wrong things she did. It was the best moment because somebody needed to set things straight with her

Cons -

Third Act/Final Act - The film was going pretty solid so far. That was until the third act or the part where Roger was bailed out of jail for destruction to somebody's car and putting someone in the hospital. After that part, I personally felt like the story kind of fell apart. Nimfa does have a guilty mind for the decisions she made, which is understandable. But here is one that I felt like fell apart: Nimfa getting pregnant with Roger's baby. This was when literally Nimfa and Iningo finished having sex on the beach. She was pregnant next day and it was Roger's baby. I was confused because they havent had sex in a while! She was pretty much banging Iningo. Plus, I felt like this was a bit out of place for something like a pregnancy to happen. There are more to it but watch the film. You'll understand why I felt like the third act of the film kind of just fell apart. Not only that but the ending felt so unsatisfying. Since the third act pretty much broke apart, the ending felt unsatisfying

Overall, A solid movie at best. Of course the story is pretty much basic but with a neat rwist. I just felt like the movie was dragged down by the third act of the film

Past the Vulgar Theme is a Message: The Theme: Past the dirty jokes and the sex theme of this movie is a filipino masterpiece, no doubt about that. Congratulations to the makers of this film. It's not usual that Filipinos brave an animated movie production like this, so kudos to you guys for that.

The Production: Angelica, Sam and Empoy are personalities fit for their roles. The dubbing could have been improved though. This caveat for me is that there are some scenes where the emotions and interaction of the characters seem so disconnected with each other. Did they record separately? Together? It's not majority of the movie but there are just some scenes that felt like they aren't talking to each other but are just speaking in character by themselves.

But the character design, the vulgarity of the screenplay, I agree that these are great creative routes for marketing purposes. They worked for me.

And I like that this movie was able to feature a pinoy world in a not so cliche way... the saleslady, the pares house, papa george.. seeing filipino icons in an animation is so funny itself. I love these.

The Story: The ending is definitely THE conversation starter. Why did she 'happily' come back to that pares house with jerry? Isn't that place what she's trying to leave for so long? Or was it really roger she's been tired already?

Is the ending a picture of failure? As in going back to square one or zero?

Or is it a depiction of a second chance at love at the same start?

I don't know the answers but I'm happy to be intrigued.

Good job and again congratulations to the team behind this. :)

Philippine Animation at its best: I loved every single bit of it. From the animation, to the witty dialogue, to the story (you'll like it better once you're aware that it's supposed to be a parody of Filipino teleserye romcom tropes), and even the music. As contrary to what some might have said about it, I actually find it to be pretty woke and progressive, with its not-so-subtle nods to current social issues such as contractualization, police brutality, etc. Like, there was even a scene in the film where you can find a poster with Duterte's face on it depicted as a literal dog; how can you be more woke than that? Politics aside, I really enjoyed the film overall. I hope Hayop Ka! manages to inspire more Filipino creatives to express the wonder of Filipino culture more and to be able to show to the world how amazing Filipino talent can be.

A visual feast: A visual feast. I have to pause the scenes every once in a while to appreciate every details. Imagine our chaotic metropolis interpreted by impressionist artist exploding with colors and lights. Dark scenes highlighted with glimmering lights inbetween and daytime landscapes so detailed that even captured the tangled electric cables, bumper to bumper traffic, rusty rooftops and most realities in the city we live in and yet somehow so mesmerizing to see in their own way. The same studio that created Saving Sally, you can easily tell their signature style that separates them from other animation studios here and globally. Much like Cartoon Saloon, an animation studio based in Ireland (Song of the Sea, Bread Winner to name a few of their movies) focus on their unique styles of visuals in their story telling. Each cells worthy to be printed, framed and hanged in your living room. Kudos to the talented creatives and artists. You are making a difference indeed.

I was pretty much on the bandwagon with this movie, mostly because of the devoted effort that the animators have worked on from Rocketsheep Studio's last film from 2016, Saving Sally, a beautifully made film mixing animated and live-action elements in a seamless polish, only to be pulled down with a standard plot and intolerable characters. So even with my skewed expectations for this film, I still do hope that this would fare better, and...It does, but it does not at the same time. So I may as well start out with the cons before the pros, and these have to do with the story and themes itself and how the tone can clash with the animation. Given that it's rated 18, the themes that it tackles do fit well, but how they are executed is in poor taste, which does remind me of how Saving Sally executes its own mature themes, but at least this film gives these themes a bit more room for discussion, even if it's dealt with in a sour, and sometimes questionable manner. The story is simple yet dramatic and can hit some good moments. I just wished it was a bit longer and does not cut through dramatic scene to dramatic scene so quickly, which made the resolution and ending so spotty, unsatisfying, and utterly rushed. The overall tone can clash with the animation in a consistent way, as some scenes do not mesh well with the hyperbolic nature of the animation, which can make some of the melodramatic scenes to be unfit and oddly uncomfortable with the cinematic and energetic flow of the animation.Pushing the flaws aside, I will say that the animation is excellent all throughout. Smooth, expressive, and gives the characters a lot of personality. The backgrounds are detailed with anthro versions of real-life brands, mottos, and references which gives more attention to detail to the movie. And the performances for the most part are also in their A-game as well, especially Angelica Panganiban.Even despite my mixed feelings for this movie, I still do want to convince everyone to watch the film, because if the film managed to succeed in its streaming sales, then that would determine how many animated films would go down the line in the years to come. And hey, with the animation this good, who wouldn't be excited for more locally animated films such as this one?

Even with all the controversy behind it recently, we want "Hayop Ka!" ("You Animal!") to succeed. The film is a technical marvel with its animation and is truly a showcase on what our local artists can do. But nothing can save it from its very simple and one-sided characters and narrative - that have no redeeming values or whatsoever. Nimfa Dimaano (Angelica Panganiban) is a pretty cat who works as a perfume sales lady at a department store. Her boyfriend is Roger (Robin Padilla) who works as a janitor and already happy and satisfied with his standing in life. But Nimfa wants more and when she meets I√±igo Villanueva (Sam Milby), a super rich business dog, their chemistry ignites. Who will Nimfa choose? Roger‚Äôs unending love or I√±igo‚Äôs unending riches?Taking years to make, it seemed like much of the effort in creating "Hayop Ka!" was put into crafting its world of parody. If you're a Filipino viewer then every scene will be oozing with inside jokes that it was actually as amusing as the animation itself. Speaking of the animation, this is the strongest asset for "Hayop Ka!". The colorful and vibrant environments and palette make every scene stand out and the 2D animation had the perfect mix of feeling nostalgic and modern at the same time. The voice acting was good but not great. While the voice actors themselves handled the script well, there's just this feeling that the visuals and audio didn't match up 100%. Unfortunately, the film had poorly-written characters and narrative. It was too simple to the point that the characters themselves were one-sided and extremely flawed. The characters do "bad things" and there's little chance for them to redeem themselves given the film's running time of 98 minutes. We understand that this is a raunchy comedy but putting non-redeemable characters just for the sake of being in tone with its theme was a bad decision in our opinion. Overall though, "Hayop Ka!" at least had excellent comedy and visuals that will make you laugh - just don't expect to get anything else from the experience. Story and writing: 2.5/5Animation: 4/5Characters and voice acting: 3.5/5Overall score: 10/15Rating: Decent (3.33/5)Song: "Love Me Like You Do" by Ellie Goulding (from "50 Shades of Grey") - youtu.be/AJtDXIazrMoBeing Singaporean, it's such a pleasant surprise that Southeast Asian animation is getting better and better each year given that it's a very small industry in the region, even in 2020. I got to be honest, 2020 is the year where the small and low-budget animated movies managed to be at times on par with the mainstream giants. Hayop Ka (or You Animal), from the Philippines' Rocketsheep Studios (who also produced the unique hybrid movie "Saving Sally") should be included on that list.The story parodies on classic Filippino soap oprea tropes, in that it's a love triangle between a saleslady, her janitor boyfriend and a rich businessman whom she feel in love with the first time they encountered each other. One of the best things about the story is that it's one of the funniest animated movies of the year. The amount of animal-related puns, innuendos and sexual tensions justify the M18 rating there, but it also sacrificed the cohesion and flow of the love triangle, an absolute shame given that it's the writing that mainly let the whole movie down (also, a little bit too many storylines to cover in such a short frame). Still, for their first animated movie attempt, the story is still enjoyable to a certain extent.But, let's talk about the most surprising element of the movie: the animation. This is easily well animated. I know I prefer 2D animation to 3D CGI, but for an animated movie made in the Philippines, this is a solid attempt! There are moments where the colours are a little bit flat, but when the animation gets dynamic, it shows the full potential of its animation and we rarely get this type of animation anymore. Kudos to the guys at Rocketsheep for such great animation.As for characters, most of the main cast are full realised, although given its 73-minute runtime, some of the development felt rushed. I feel for the main character Nimfa (voiced by Angelica Panganiban) as she struggled to keep her affection with the rich businessman a secret as well as the two main male leads. If the story is a letdown, the entertaining characters did not.I will give Hayop Ka credit for one thing: they should not be underestimated when it comes to low budget animated movies that came out in 2020, especially when it's easily one of the most entertaining low budget animated movies of 2020. It's currently available in most Asian countries that has Netflix, so if you can't wait to support Filippino animation but you are outside Asia, do keep a lookout for its release in other countries on Netflix. Trust me, Hayop Ka is a great surprise, but I truly wish for 10 to 15 more minutes of this great animated and furry parody of typical Filippino soap opreas.

It gives the sister a bit more depth that she is not solely living off FL's allowance and is actually serious about earning her keep. But it was just downplayed, as if it didn't happen. Like whuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuut I mean per se its funny, it's just a bit out of place.4) At its current state, the writing is just an excuse to make the film rather than the basis of the film. I'm referring to FL discovering she is (A) pregnant not with her current BF but with her recent ex, (B) who happens to now be with her best friend and all the while (C) her sister is also pregnant. The way I would see it is her sister represents hope so seeing that hope broken also affects her. Another depth is the FL is now being a hypocrite by not practicing what she preach which is use contraception to avoid unwanted pregnancy . As you can see, there are a lot of events that carry the film. If only that drama happened much earlier and they tackled it properly with proper thought process, it would have be a concrete film. I wasn‚Äôt planning on writing reviews when i made a letterboxd account. I just wanted to lurk, read reviews, check out people‚Äôs lists, stalk user profiles and yes, read every single review to every movie I directed because i like crying myself to sleep at night. But after watching hayop ka and reading the reviews here, i was compelled to write something. Because i don‚Äôt get why people hate it so much. For me, it‚Äôs a dark comedy that tackles realities of class and socio-economic disparity in the Philippines. Nimfa‚Äôs problem is simple: she‚Äôs poor. She has to break her back working as a saleslady to pay for her sister‚Äôs tuition and pay rent, she has pares to look forward to during special occasions because that‚Äôs all she and her boyfriend could afford, she can‚Äôt even go to a motel for some sexy time. This isn‚Äôt necessary a problem except for one thing: Nimfa is dissatisfied. She is not happy with her situation. She wants more. But what can she do? She didn‚Äôt graduate and it‚Äôs very likely that she‚Äôll be a saleslady forever. So can you really blame her when she ‚Äúfalls‚Äù for I√±igo? A handsome rich guy who showers her with attention? If you were in her situation, wouldn‚Äôt you? I would. So she makes one bad choice after another. Should we hate her for it? What would we rather see? Tanggapin nalang niya yung buhay niyang ganun? Ok lang yang pares ghorl masarap naman. Beauty in poverty ganun? She sees a way out, and she grabs it. I am not entirely happy with her choice but i understand why she did it. Eh sa sawa nang maging mahirap ‚Äôyung tao e. The bad choices that Nimfa makes are greatly influenced by her circumstances, circumstances that are forced upon her because she is poor. Yes cliche. Yes lagi nalang mahirap/mayaman storyline but maybe there‚Äôs a reason why the boss-katulong trope(the powerful loving the powerless) works so well in our country. Maybe it‚Äôs because most of us Filipinos still see that as the only means of escape.And hayop ka lays bare that truth: If you‚Äôre poor, falling in love out of economic need is very much a reality. This truth is prevalent in our narratives, even if they aren‚Äôt explicitly stated. Some top of mind examples are Laida Magtalas falling in love with sir Miggy(A very special love) or Maya with Sir Chief(be careful with my heart). Fuck i‚Äôm oldüò≠üò≠ The difference in hayop ka is that it does away with romantics and explicitly states, with ice cold pragmatism: I am in love with you because I am poor, because you are my best option to escape this life. It‚Äôs tragic how in the world presented in hayop ka, genuine romantic love is a privilege for the rich.And another note, can i just say that the art direction is fucking gorgeous. Making drawings move is an expensive and time-consuming affair and you have to find ways to get your point across in as few frames as possible. Hayop ka borrows some techniques from Japanese animation which it uses brilliantly and comically. Future animations will surely use this film as a reference.-1 half star lang pala for too much sexual jokes. Not that im offended or anything and i‚Äôm totally fine with women exhibiting the same sexual libido and desire as men, it‚Äôs just that there were too many and most of them weren‚Äôt funny. -1 half star ulit for the ending with empoy the frog. I get that the film had to end on a somewhat lighthearted note, after it literally kicked rich prince charming out the window, mejo corny lang yung promo ng walang ka paris and laughter laughter. Other than that, methinks this is a solid film that illustrates the relationship that exist between class and love. Liongoren's Hayop Ka! is a tongue-in-cheek and provocative 2D animated film seen from the perspective of proletariat catwoman Nimfa Dimaano, as she finds herself slowly loosening her morals in desperate exchange of economic indemnity. The film is deceptively simple, but functions intelligently to provide a scathing representation of the cyclical, problematic lives of the working class Filipino: their desensitisation to the methods they cling onto for their own economic benefit, the internalized sexist and especially misogynistic paradigm that remains hegemonic among both Filipino men and women, and how all this disturbingly becomes the mundanity of everyday life in a third-world country. Moreover, although the narrative might simply appear as an animated rehash of what has plagued local TV for years, it cleverly utilizes these teleserye tropes to construct a sociological examination on capitalism's destruction to society; more specifically, to the Filipinos that belong to the lower end of the social strata. Past the painfully realistic reconstruction of the plight of the working class in film, the portrayal on the bourgeoisie is also excellently handled; they're cruel and selfish, despite the already comfortable lives that they live. Hence, the anthropomorphism of these animals becomes a clever display of how capitalism has made literal animals out of us‚Äî easily succumbing to carnal desires and almost devoid of empathy.Aside from the thematic complexity of Hayop Ka!, the meticulously beautiful animation is extremely noteworthy as well. Sadly, this film has been misread by most of its viewers‚Äî its intelligent writing and thematic complexity ignored due to its vulgar, yet realistically absurd humor. Needless to say, Hayop Ka! is up there thematically, and can even suffice to be the lovechild of two classics that eloquently critique capitalism: last year's Parasite, and 1962 Mexican film The Exterminating Angel. Definitely one of the year's best!

You have no idea the effort I put in to actually watch this, and I can't really recommend it to anybody else - an animated film with spot-on Cartoon Network aesthetics, relentless sex jokes, and a setting (Metro Manila) where I spent a lot of my formative years. Clearly, this work was calling me.So let me make this plain: this film's sexual and gender politics are - put charitably - regressive. The humor is largely juvenile, with not a single innuendo left unsaid. And the story is propelled by thoroughly unlikable characters.But... I was ultimately entertained. A large part of that was just pure nostalgia for the Phillipines, getting to see all signifiers I remembered (The Supermall! Jeepnies!) and several I forgot (the wire mesh displays for drinks, holy shit!) The animation and design are lovely, but are helped by some truly genius visual comedy and meme references. And for as selfish as our protagonists are, I thought their motives made sense. The story may go full soap opera, but at least it's never boring.From what I've seen on Letterboxd, most of the reviews compliment the film's look but criticize it for perpetuating tropes of clasism and misogyny that are apparently well-represented in Filipino media. For all the time I spent living there, I never really watched much that was locally made, and am only vaguely familiar with the craziness that has been going on with the current government.As a piece of satire, I thought this worked. But, I'm also not the smartest guy I know.

Pero sayang, kasi lahat ng ganda, tinabunan ng isang script na parang binunot sa pinakababa ng basura ng Philippine showbiz.Nakakabwisit yung sobrang sexualization ng mga karakter. Oo, satire daw. Pero ang kinalabasan, parang hyper-sexualized telenovela na hindi malaman kung seryoso ba siyang commentary sa class divide o gusto lang niyang gawing "bomba cartoon" si Nimfa. The first time I watched Hayop Ka!, I honestly just saw it as a bastos movie, parang puro kabastusan lang HAHA. But upon rewatching it, I realized the concept is actually liberating and surprisingly close to reality. Its vibrancy and exaggerated humor felt more like satire‚Äîa playful but biting critique of how consumerism shapes the world we live in.Through a realist lens, the film mirrors the everyday struggles of many Filipinos, though wrapped in an animated, comedic package. The stark contrast between the rich and the poor was a constant theme. How privilege dictates not only opportunities but also relationships. Even love in the film is framed by class and material wealth, showing how affection is often entangled with survival and status.From a Marxist perspective, Nimfa‚Äôs relationships expose how capitalism and consumerism seep into our most intimate desires. Her dissatisfaction with her current boyfriend and her attraction to a wealthier partner may seem superficial at first, but it reflects how the system conditions people to equate love with upward mobility and financial security. The film satirizes how consumer culture commodifies even emotions and human connection, turning them into transactions rather than purely personal bonds.Looking at it through feminist theory naman, my initial impression of Nimfa as "malandi" for wanting more felt unfair. On rewatch, I realized this judgment reflects how women are often shamed for pursuing their desires, especially if those desires break away from traditional expectations. The film suggests that Nimfa‚Äôs choices are not purely personal flaws but rather shaped by the larger forces of patriarchy and capitalism, where women are pressured to chase an ‚Äúideal‚Äù version of love, security, and femininity. It questions why women are criticized for seeking better lives, while men who fail to provide are rarely scrutinized in the same way.In the end, Hayop Ka! may seem chaotic and shallow at first glance, but digging deeper, it becomes a satirical mirror of our society; where class, consumerism, and gender roles intersect to shape even the most personal aspects of life like love and relationships.

I really wish I could figure out just why this is rated so low on Letterboxd. If ever there was a movie I wanted to have a conversation about, this is it, because I fail to see why this really fun, slightly dramatic, but overall interesting slice of life is so universally panned. I think it goes without saying to praise the animation in Hayop-ka - it‚Äôs smooth and moves fluidly, it leaves itself open for some really impressive expressions and powerful images in scenes. The backgrounds are picturesque, and create a very vivid feeling of what this version of the Philippines is like: lively, energetic, maybe a little crowded but full of interesting characters. I think it‚Äôs worth mentioning, too, how good these backgrounds are at communicating different regions: the scenic beach near the luxury cabin, the quiet village that‚Äôs contrasted by its tight knit sense of community, both contrasted against the usual setting of the city. And while I‚Äôve seen in other reviews that people find the innuendos in the background jokes to be tacky or in poor taste, I actually found that not only were a lot of them funny, but I think it creates a tangible sense of a world populated by Anthro animals more than other media tends to. I think sex is a pretty natural human experience, and a lot of real life marketing sells sex very transparently, and lots of mainstream Anthro animation doesn‚Äôt address that. It‚Äôs outside the ratings for films like Zootopia and Sing, and sexuality is so central a focus of a story like Beastars that normalizing it would kind of destroy its themes. And I think that perhaps Hayop-Ka‚Äôs depiction of sexuality in this world is one of its greatest strengths. Which, I guess, is interesting, because it seems like part of the negative backlash to Hayop-Ka is the accusation that is perverse or obscene for its sexual nature. Which seems‚Ä¶ weird to me. The sex isn‚Äôt explicit in it, and Nimpha is only pictured having sex in the film once. The films setting is steeped in sexuality: sexuality is marketed on every sign on every street, and Nimpha‚Äôs motivation is mostly based around sex,But it doesn‚Äôt feel that weird I guess? It‚Äôs a story about an adult woman making adult choices, and the use of sexuality is only out of place because it‚Äôs animation - but there‚Äôs a lot of animated stories that are a lot more sexual than this. And like I said, I think the sexuality makes the plot kind of interesting. By the third act, the novelty of animal-sex-world kinda dies off, and the film isn‚Äôt really about that, as it becomes a series of Nimpha making increasingly more destructive decisions with basically everyone involved in her life. But by that point in the film, I had already been hooked in, and I was interested in what would happen to Nimpha. The positive sexual expression was a great hook for the first act, and moving into the second and third, I cared enough about the established characters enough to weigh the morality of their decisions in my head. Nimpha does something objectively bad to Roger, but it is understandable that she wants to better herself, and Roger‚Äôs tendency towards violence make him seem like a less dependable partner. But Inigo‚Äôs a literal villain, and if him talking about partnering with Elon musk didn‚Äôt telegraph that enough, he is a character who openly talks about working with the Filipino president to keep wages down. When Nimpha confronts her family in the third act, she‚Äôs objectively wrong, but I can‚Äôt really be mad at her, because it‚Äôs a realistic emotional outburst. I‚Äôve watched a lot of stories about bad people who misuse sexuality in their lives. And I‚Äôll never claim that Hayop-Ka - an animated parody of soap operas meant to poke fun at infidelity - is even half as weighty as T√°r or Bojack Horseman - heavy commentary about how celebrity is used to leverage power. But, I do file this movie in a similar place in my head. Watching a not great person try to be better and trying to figure out why things are so messy. And frankly!!! I actually adore the ending for that. Because Nimfa does fuck up, she does do bad things, but people in her life do bad things back to her. And in the end the best thing Nimfa can do is just‚Ä¶ walk away. Start a new life. And she does and I think that‚Äôs beautiful. I do think it‚Äôs worth mentioning the sexist overtones in the climax of the movie - when Nimfa calls the radio station. A reference to an unfortunately very real trend of men berating women for doing anything other than serving whatever man is already present in her life. I feel like part of the negative reception of Hayop Ka is that people read this as him being right but like‚Ä¶ no?? He‚Äôs just not? Maybe it‚Äôs my prior knowledge making me biased against a man in a recording booth telling a woman how to live her life, but in that moment I think it‚Äôs Nimfa‚Äôs last attempt to rely on men, and her faith in it is shattered when she talks to Inigo again. Because yeah - don‚Äôt know if you notice - she can‚Äôt even try to follow that bull‚Äôs advice, because she never gets a chance to come clean to Inigo if she wanted to. And I think that Nimfa marching for maternity leave and raising her child on her own with her family shows that Nimfa‚Äôs life isn‚Äôt going to revolve around the approval of men anymore. It‚Äôs possible that‚Äôs cope: that this is a sexist message I‚Äôm jumping through hoops to spin in a way that empowers the protagonist in the end. But I dunno, I kinda constructed that reading without thinking about it. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs that much of a stretch.I‚Äôm going to be coming back to Hayop-Ka at some point, for sure. It‚Äôs filed in my brain alongside a lot of my favorite depictions of every day life in an animal world. It‚Äôs a little melodramatic, but I do think that the depiction of Nimfa, and how her story ends, does tell a good, grounded story. I think I, a bunny, am always going to be happy with a film that I start and whose title very loudly says to me,‚ÄúYou‚Äôre an animal‚Äù

Before I start being critical I have to say, this movie being the first that the Philippines didn't outsource for animation and was made in the country is really neat, along with the fact the animation just looks good, It is very good at comedy and changing art styles for effect, I got some good laughs out of it becoming hyper realistic during the sexy time parts, also the character designs are nice, Jerry objectively being my favorite because...well I love frogs and he's stylized really good, a perfect little guy design.Anyways, the plot was uh...well it was okay I guess? I found it to be a bit too melodramatic for my taste, and while I suppose you can say it is because of it being a satire on the way the tropes in Filipino media act, but even then I feel like it missed the ball sometimes. Sometimes it does good, I like the end credits of our main character learning to not be as much of a piece of shit, but something about it urks me, you know? Another person had mentioned how sort of misogynistic this movie is, and how while sometimes it does good in relation to satirizing the concepts shown, sometimes it just uh...doesn't I guess? It sort of goes well, we were satirizing this but now we mean it genuinely I suppose. This isn't me being against characters who are shitty people like the way it is in this movie, I love bad people doing awful things to each other, maybe its the cheating aspect or the over exaggeration but it comes off as more of a smear against women who want more in life. I can't blame our main character to want to be living comfortably, she works a dead end job and wants to be happy, I'm not defending her, by any stretch of the imagination, fuck her, but I feel this aura of sinister intentions. As a whole this movie is beautiful when it comes to animation, but the story is overly dramatic to the point of it being more stupid than anything else, and while the fact it is a satire saves it sometimes, other times it really isn't satirical and just dumb. Go watch it though just for the animation and some of the jokes. Maybe just once if you can't stand stupidity in your movies, but it is worth the watch.

Hayop Ka! is this unusual yet entertaining animated film driven by a sexual frenzy with an insatiable appetite. The film is a romantic smorgasbord of lust with a final act that is smashed between a triple cheeseburger of twists.
Thanks to delightful animation design and charming voice work, we know immediately that this is supposed to be silly, slightly naughty fun, not something smutty or salacious.
You Animal! (Hayop Ka!) offers a boisterous swirl of sass, sex and soap opera hysterics.
Hayop Ka! is mostly bark, and barely any bites.
